courses.name: Human Language
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 1060, C_S_D 1060, ENGLSH 1060).  General introduction to various aspects of linguistic study. Elementary analysis of language data, with some attention to application of linguistic study to other disciplines.

courses.name: Topics in Linguistics-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Anthropological Linguistics
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 2040). Language in relation to other aspects of human behavior. Introduction to description and analysis of the basic units of language. Emphasis on non-Indo-European and preliterate languages.

courses.name: Languages of Africa
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2601 and ENGLSH 2601). Introduction to the diversity of the 2000+ African languages, including first-hand experience exploring a few in detail with native speakers.  Features of African languages are compared with others of the world.  Political and social aspects of language in Africa are discussed.

courses.name: Elementary Logic
courses.description: (same as PHIL 2700). Introduces a symbolic language for representing the structure of arguments. Presents precise rules for demonstrating the validity of arguments. Covers natural deduction for sentence and predicate logic. Develops skill in constructing derivations.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or higher in MATH 1100 or MATH 1120

courses.name: Introduction to Cognitive Science
courses.description: (same as PSYCH 2820 and PHIL 2820).  Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary study of the mind.  After an overview of the foundations of cognitive science as a whole, we will see what particular sectors of it have to say about mental capacities such as vision, language, categorization, and social cognition.

courses.name: Topics in Linguistics-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: American Phonetics
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 3010). Analysis of production and acoustics of the sounds of speech with an emphasis on American English; practice in broad and narrow transcription using the International Phonetic Alphabet.

courses.name: Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech Mechanism
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 3210). Introduction to anatomical and functional aspects of the speech mechanism.

courses.name: Speech Acoustics
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 3220).  An introduction to the acoustic aspects of speech as they relate to the respiratory, phonatory, resonatory, and articulatory systems.

courses.name: Culture as Communication
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 3470, COMMUN 3470). Study of the influence of culture on communication processes. Examines topics such as the impact of values, languages, and nonverbal behavior on intercultural interaction.

courses.name: Survey of Minority and Creole Languages of the U.S. and the Caribbean
courses.description: (same as SPAN 3710 and FRENCH 3710). Analysis of the state of the minority languages of the U.S. and the Creole languages of the Caribbean with particular attention to the social status of these languages and speakers' attitudes toward them in context of ethnic, cultural, and national identity (taught in English).

courses.name: Spanish Phonetics
courses.description: (same as SPAN 3721). Introductory course to the study of Spanish phonological, phonetic and spelling systems, practice of pronunciation, phonetic transcriptions, and introduction to the variation of Spanish pronunciation in the Hispanic world.  The course is conducted in Spanish.

courses.name: Topics in Linguistics-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Topics in Linguistics-General - Writing Intenisve
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Philosophy of Language
courses.description: (same as PHIL 4100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing and PHIL 2700 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Logic
courses.description: (same as PHIL 4110; cross-leveled with LINGST 7110). Presents the method of truth trees for sentence and predicate logic. Examines proofs concerning the decidability, soundness, and completeness of formal systems. Emphasizes the theory of formal systems.
courses.prerequisites: sophomore standing and PHIL 2700; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Old English
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4200). A beginning study of the Old English or Anglo-Saxon language in its cultural context, with emphasis on gaining a reading knowledge.

courses.name: Language and Culture
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4400). Interrelations between language, thought, culture, and society; role of language in cognition; methods and concepts of linguistics in cultural analysis.

courses.name: Gender, Language and Communication
courses.description: (same as COMMUN 4412 and ANTHRO 4412). Relationships among gender, language, nonverbal communication, and culture.

courses.name: Language and Discourse
courses.description: (same as COMMUN 4415). Analysis of the rules of social interaction and the functions of language in discourse.

courses.name: Historical Linguistics
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4420). Methods of tracing the history of languages by glottochronology, and by comparative and internal reconstructions; cultural and linguistic implications of such reconstructions and of areal linguistics.

courses.name: Structure of American English
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4600). Introduction to English linguistics. Study of the grammar and pronunciation of contemporary English, with the major focus on syntax.

courses.name: History of the English Language
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4610). Historical changes in the grammar and pronunciation of the English language from Old English to the present. Introduction to Indo-European origins of English.

courses.name: Regional and Social Dialects of American English
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4620). The study of regional and social variation in pronunciation, vocabulary, and syntax of American English.

courses.name: Phonology
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4630). Survey of the sound patterns of English, with some comparison to other languages.

courses.name: Syntax
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 4640). Study of the properties of phrase and sentence-level grammar, emphasizing English, with some comparison to other languages.

courses.name: Principles of Teaching English as a Second Language
courses.description: (same as LTC 4460). Linguistic and pedagogical principles of teaching English to speakers of other languages.

courses.name: History of the French Language
courses.description: (same as FRENCH 4710). Study of the French language from its Latin origin to the present.  The course includes a survey of the external, social, political, and historical factors that have affected the development of French, followed by diachronic study of the internal structural features of the language.

courses.name: History of the Spanish Language
courses.description: (same as SPAN 4711). Diachronic analysis of phonological morphological, and syntactical systems of Spanish, from Vulgar Latin to contemporary dialects.

courses.name: Structure of Modern French
courses.description: (same as FRENCH 4720). An introductory presentation of the phonological and syntactic systems of contemporary standard French.

courses.name: Structure of Modern Spanish
courses.description: (same as SPAN 4721). Synchronic analysis of phonology morphology and syntax of spoken Spanish dialects.

courses.name: Spanish Across the Continents
courses.description: (same as SPAN 4722).  This course focuses on the effects of migratory movements on language change, considering the Spanish spoken in Latin America, Puerto Rico, Spain and the USA.  The class sharpens awareness and recognition of the linguistic diversity of the Spanish-speaking regions of the world.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Language and Society
courses.description: (same as SPAN 4723). This class surveys linguistic and social issues pertaining to Spanish in the U.S. (past, present and future).  Topics include bilingualism, code switching (a.k.a. Spanglish), first language attrition, linguistic identity, and the role of Spanish in Education, services and media.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Linguistic Theory and Language Acquisition
courses.description: The goal of this class is to study the implications of current linguistic theory for contemporary research on second language acquisition. In particular, the hypothesis that second language acquisition follows some of the same principles as first language acquisition is explored. Course is taught in English.

courses.name: Interdisciplinary Introduction to NLP
courses.description: (same as CMP_SC 4740; cross-leveled with LINGST 7740). The goal of this course is to enable students to develop substantive NLP applications.  Focus on current structural and statistical techniques for the parsing and interpretation of texts.

courses.name: Psycholinguistics
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 4810). Examination of the knowledge and processes that underlie the human ability to produce and understand language.

courses.name: Speech Perception
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 4820). Selected topics in the perceptual processing of spoken language.

courses.name: Practical Phonetics for Fieldwork
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4850). Self-paced course using computer and tape recorded lessons from world's languages. Teaches practical articulatory and transcription phonetics. Weekly meeting with instructor to monitor progress, resolve questions.

courses.name: Techniques in Linguistic Analysis
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4860). Problems in analyzing data from various languages.

courses.name: Field Methods in Linguistics
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4870 and ENGLSH 4670). Intensive training in collection and analysis of data taken from a native speaker of non-Indo-European language.

courses.name: Field Methods in Linguistics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4870 and ENGLSH 4670). Intensive training in collection and analysis of data taken from a native speaker of non-Indo-European language.

courses.name: Special Readings in Linguistics
courses.description: Independent study through readings, conferences, reports.

courses.name: Studies in Linguistics
courses.description: Topic varies according to instructor.

courses.name: Honors Thesis in Linguistics
courses.description: Based on an original research project in theoretical or applied linguistics. Topic, director, and second reader approved by Linguistics Committee, College of Arts and Science.

courses.name: Philosophy of Language
courses.description: (same as PHIL 7100).  Examination of contemporary views of the relationship between language, minds, and the world.
courses.recommendation: Some work in PHIL 1000, PHIL 3000 or PHIL 3200

courses.name: Advanced Logic
courses.description: (same as PHIL 7110; cross-leveled with LINGST 4110). Presents the method of truth trees for sentence and predicate logic. Examines proofs concerning the decidability, soundness, and completeness for formal systems. Emphasizes the theory of formal systems.

courses.name: Introduction to Old English
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7200). A beginning study of the Old English or Anglo-Saxon language in its cultural context, with emphasis on gaining a reading knowledge.

courses.name: Language and Culture
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7400). Interrelations between language, thought, culture, and society; role of language in cognition; methods and concepts of linguistics in cultural analysis.

courses.name: Gender, Language, and Communication
courses.description: (same as COMMUN 7412 and ANTHRO 7412). Relationships among gender, language, nonverbal communication, and culture.

courses.name: Language and Discourse
courses.description: (same as COMMUN 7415). Analysis of the rules of social interaction and the functions of language in discourse.

courses.name: Historical Linguistics
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7420). Methods of tracing the history of languages by glottochronology, and by comparative and internal reconstructions; cultural and linguistic implications of such reconstructions and of areal linguistics.

courses.name: Structure of American English
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7600). Introduction to English linguistics. Study of the grammar and pronunciation of contemporary English, with the major focus on syntax.

courses.name: History of the English Language
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7610). Historical changes in the grammar and pronunciation of the English language from Old English to the present. Introduction to Indo-European origins of English.

courses.name: Regional and Social Dialects of American English
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7620). The study of regional and social variation in pronunciation, vocabulary, and syntax of American English.
courses.prerequisites: LINGST 4600 or LINGST 7600 and LINGST 7610 or equivalent

courses.name: Phonology
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7630). Survey of the sound patterns of English, with some comparison to other languages.
courses.prerequisites: LINGST 7600 or another introductory course in linguistics or phonetics

courses.name: Syntax
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 7640). Study of the properties of phrase-and sentence-level grammar, emphasizing English, with some comparison to other languages.
courses.prerequisites: LINGST 4600 or another comparable linguistics course

courses.name: Principles of Teaching English as a Second Language
courses.description: (cross-leveled with LINGST 4650). Linguistic and pedagogical principles of teaching English to speakers of other languages.

courses.name: History of the French Language
courses.description: (same as FRENCH 7710).

courses.name: History of the Spanish Language
courses.description: (same as SPAN 7711). Diachronic analysis of Spanish phonology, morphology, and syntax from Vulgar Latin to modern period.
courses.prerequisites: completed with passing grade any Linguistics course 3000 or above or by instructor's consent

courses.name: Structure of Modern French
courses.description: (same as FRENCH 7720). An introductory presentation of the phonological and syntactic systems of contemporary standard French.

courses.name: Structure of Modern Spanish
courses.description: (same as SPAN 7721). Synchronic analysis of phonology morphology and syntax of spoken Spanish dialects.

courses.name: Linguistic Theory and Language Acquisition
courses.description: (same as RM_LAN 7730).  The goal of this class is to study the implications of current linguistic theory for contemporary research on second language acquisition. In particular, the hypothesis that second language acquisition follows some of the same principles as first language acquisition is explored. Course is taught in English.

courses.name: Interdisciplinary Introduction to Natural Language Processing
courses.description: (same as CMP_SC 7740; cross-leveled with LINGST 4740). The goal of this course is to enable students to develop substantive NLP applications. Focus on current structural and statistical techniques for the parsing and interpretation of text.

courses.name: Psycholinguistics
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 7810). Examines the knowledge and processes that underlie the human ability to produce and understand language.

courses.name: Speech Perception
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 7820).  Selected topics in the perceptual processing of speech sounds and spoken language.

courses.name: Practical Phonetics for Fieldwork
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7850). Self-paced course using computer and tape recorded lessons from world's languages. Teaches practical articulatory and transcription phonetics. Weekly meeting with instructor to monitor progress, resolve questions.

courses.name: Techniques in Linguistic Analysis
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7860). Problems in analyzing data from various languages.
courses.prerequisites: introductory course in Linguistics or instructor's consent

courses.name: Field Methods in Linguistics
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7870 and ENGLSH 7670). Intensive training in collection and analysis of data taken from a native speaker of non-Indo-European language.

courses.name: Problems
courses.description: Independent study through readings, analysis of special linguistic problems, reports.
courses.prerequisites: one Advanced Linguistics course and instructor's consent

courses.name: Speech Science
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 8100). Introduction to the physiological and acoustic aspects of speech production; instrumentation for speech analysis including computer-based speech processing techniques.
courses.prerequisites: C_S_D 3010, C_S_D 3210, and C_S_D 3230 or equivalents

courses.name: Speech Physiology
courses.description: (same as C_S_D 8110). Analysis of physiological features associated with speech subsystems; theories of encoding with special emphasis on speech motor control mechanisms.

courses.name: Bilingualism and Language Contact
courses.description: (same as SPAN 8120 and FRENCH 8120). Global analysis of the study of Bilingualism from a combined sociocultural, sociolinguistic and psycholinguistic perspective based on current research and examination of various phenomena of language contact (taught in Eng.).

courses.name: Seminar in Anthropological Linguistics
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 8487). Topics: Ethnolinguistics, linguistic prehistory, pidgin and Creole languages, linguistic theories and cultural and cultural analysis. French structural anthropology. May be repeated for 9 hours maximum.

courses.name: Seminar in the English Language
courses.description: (same as ENGLSH 8600). Descriptive and historical studies of the English language. Topics (e.g., The Germanic Origins, Modern Syntactic Analysis) announced at time of registration. May be repeated up to twelve hours with departmental approval.

courses.name: History of the German Language
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 8615).

courses.name: Middle High German
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 8625).
